prompt: How can I create an account?
response: To create an account, click on the 'Sign Up' button on the top right corner of our website and follow the instructions to complete the registration process.

prompt: What payment methods do you accept?
response: We accept major credit cards, debit cards, and PayPal as payment methods for online orders.

prompt: How can I track my order?
response: You can track your order by logging into your account and navigating to the 'Order History' section. There, you will find the tracking information for your shipment.

prompt: What is your return policy?
response: Our return policy allows you to return products within 30 days of purchase for a full refund, provided they are in their original condition and packaging. Please refer to our Returns page for detailed instructions.

prompt: Can I cancel my order?
response: You can cancel your order if it has not been shipped yet. Please contact our customer support team with your order details, and we will assist you with the cancellation process.

prompt: How long does shipping take?
response: Shipping times vary depending on the destination and the shipping method chosen. Standard shipping usually takes 3-5 business days, while express shipping can take 1-2 business days.

prompt: Do you offer international shipping?
response: Yes, we offer international shipping to select countries. The availability and shipping costs will be calculated during the checkout process based on your location.

prompt: What should I do if my package is lost or damaged?
response: If your package is lost or damaged during transit, please contact our customer support team immediately. We will initiate an investigation and take the necessary steps to resolve the issue.

prompt: Can I change my shipping address after placing an order?
response: If you need to change your shipping address, please contact our customer support team as soon as possible. We will do our best to update the address if the order has not been shipped yet.

prompt: How can I contact customer support?
response: You can contact our customer support team by phone at [phone number] or by email at [email address]. Our team is available [working hours] to assist you with any inquiries or issues you may have.

prompt: Do you offer gift wrapping services?
response: Yes, we offer gift wrapping services for an additional fee. During the checkout process, you can select the option to add gift wrapping to your order.

prompt: What is your price matching policy?
response: We have a price matching policy where we will match the price of an identical product found on a competitor's website. Please contact our customer support team with the details of the product and the competitor's offer.

prompt: Can I order by phone?
response: Unfortunately, we do not accept orders over the phone. Please place your order through our website for a smooth and secure transaction.

prompt: Are my personal and payment details secure?
response: Yes, we take the security of your personal and payment details seriously. We use industry-standard encryption and follow strict security protocols to ensure your information is protected.

prompt: What is your price adjustment policy?
response: If a product you purchased goes on sale within 7 days of your purchase, we offer a one-time price adjustment. Please contact our customer support team with your order details to request the adjustment.

prompt: Do you have a loyalty program?
response: Yes, we have a loyalty program where you can earn points for every purchase. These points can be redeemed for discounts on future orders. Please visit our website to learn more and join the program.

prompt: Can I order without creating an account?
response: Yes, you can place an order as a guest without creating an account. However, creating an account offers benefits such as order tracking and easier future purchases.

prompt: Do you offer bulk or wholesale discounts?
response: Yes, we offer bulk or wholesale discounts for certain products. Please contact our customer support team or visit our Wholesale page for more information and to discuss your specific requirements.

prompt: Can I change or cancel an item in my order?
response: If you need to change or cancel an item in your order, please contact our customer support team as soon as possible. We will assist you with the necessary steps.

prompt: How can I leave a product review?
response: To leave a product review, navigate to the product page on our website and click on the 'Write a Review' button. You can share your feedback and rating based on your experience with the product.

prompt: Can I use multiple promo codes on a single order?
response: Usually, only one promo code can be applied per order. During the checkout process, enter the promo code in the designated field to apply the discount to your order.

prompt: What should I do if I receive the wrong item?
response: If you receive the wrong item in your order, please contact our customer support team immediately. We will arrange for the correct item to be shipped to you and assist with returning the wrong item.

prompt: Do you offer expedited shipping?
response: Yes, we offer expedited shipping options for faster delivery. During the checkout process, you can select the desired expedited shipping method.

prompt: Can I order a product that is out of stock?
response: If a product is currently out of stock, you will usually see an option to sign up for product notifications. This way, you will be alerted when the product becomes available again.

prompt: What is your email newsletter about?
response: Our email newsletter provides updates on new product releases, exclusive offers, and helpful tips related to our products. You can subscribe to our newsletter on our website.

prompt: Can I return a product if I changed my mind?

prompt: Do you offer live chat support?

prompt: gap
response: When I bought my CP9150 kit in 2008, I used it on my '95 Mercury Cougar (OBDII) and my '91 Oldsmobile Bravada (OBDI) with no problems. Before 1996, most GM vehicles used the ALDL cable kit for OBDI computers. In "94 and '96 certain GM vehicles used the J1962 DLC. I do not know which vehicles these are. But this kit should work on either connector in your car(s). Both of these adapter cables come in the CP9150 kit, along with a few others. I hope this helps. There may be better scanner/readers out there but I'm happy with this one.

If you are using both the High, and the Low tone horns, wired in parallel (best option), then I would recommend a relay, and direct connect to the battery (with an inline fuse) for maximum power transfer, and maximum loudness.I used two sets of both horns, on two separate motorcycles, in parallel.  I also used a relay, controlled by the OEM horn circuit, with a direct connect to the batteries, for maximum volume.  A relay is less than $10 at any automotive parts store (Wal-Mart likely has the lowest price).  If you need help with electrical circuits, here is a great book's ISBN-10:  0760327165, "Motorcycle Electrical Systems: Troubleshooting and Repair (Motorbooks Workshop)".  Check your local library for a copy, or purchase it here, on Amazon.  Cheers!

prompt: Will this fit a 2014 Wrangler JK?
response:
Not sure what you are needing to know. The lower port on the back of the water heater is for the cold water supply. The upper port is for the hot water supply. If you need the water connections, the easiest way to do so is with shark bite fittings. Most campers come with 1/2" pex type water line. You can get 1/2" male shark bite fittings to make your connections. Make positively sure that you seat the water line to the bottom of the fitting or you will have a nice mess to clean up. When I install them, I use wirsbo aqua pex and my expander tool and appropriate fittings. However, if you do not have access to this it is expensive as the expander tool alone is $400.00. The shark bite fitting usually come in around $20.00. You will find the sharke bite fittings to be pretty easy, just make sure to seat them well as for warned.

response: It depends a lot on the application and duty cycle.  If you're running a continuous load, 4 A should be perfectly safe.  If you are running intermittent loads, I would not exceed 20 A, and only for short periods of time (feel the leads to see how quickly they warm up under higher loads).  These are meant for testing and prototyping, so odds are you probably aren't walking away from the area... but if you are away from the area that these are being used, it's best to make sure the loads do not exceed 4 A continuous.

I do not know what vehicle you are trying to adapt. This unit is used on vehicles that have separate lights for turn and brake signals. it combines those signals  so that the single lamp turn/brake taillight will operate. My installation is on a Ford Escape. Connection was simple and it worked right off without problems.  Just pop the taillights out or fish around the back of the vehicle, connect to 4 wires with quick connectors and screw one to ground and you are in business. If you have a permanent hitch or receiver and this is intended to be a permanent install, I recommend that you smear some silicone sealer over the quick connectors, because, salt on the roads in winter can corrode the connection and cause it to fail.

prompt: Do the jacks on the trailer have to be mounted so the feet are inline with, or perpendicular, to the frame?
response:
I emailed Meguires about a paint job on my older Ford Explorer. Seems that the body shop used a cheap clear coat over the base coat and began to haze prematurely. I suspected the clear coat was sprayed on too thin. I live in the southwest and auto paint is subject to harsh summer heat. I asked the shop to spray four clear coats but I'm sure they didn't and used some cheap stuff because paint failure happens after a couple of years but anyway, The customer care guys at Meguires suggested I use this product with a grey foam pad( I used a yellow) and my car looked like new after I finished it. The oxidized paint came right off. I also put the synthetic sealer soon afterwards and even left that on overnight to bind with the paint. You really dont need to polish your car often if you wash it by hand using a microfiber wash cloth and Meguires car wash then spray on the synthetic detailer (while car is still wet) dry off with a dry microfiber cloth. The polish is only to SLICK UP THE FINISH. Sometimes the birds get to my car and I polish that off after the hand wash but once the suface is slick and sealed, evrything will wash right off. You are right though, you go polish off some of the paint when you do this so go easy, low RPM on your rotary polisher,light pressure and remember to seal it up ! this stuff really worked well for me, I used a Dewalt rotary polisher that I purchased here on Amazon for about $150.00 a year ago. The rotary polisher is a little more difficult to use than the orbital(much lower oscillations per second) and you might want to consider that first. I have seen those at Harbour Freight Sales for about $25.00. I hope that helps !

prompt: Would these fit a 2012 Toyota Yaris?
response: This is fine "cut" cleaner, though it's called Mirror Glaze(which is confusing-look at the red meter on left, and go lower to get finer grits), and #5 is surely an abrasive for removing scratches, heavy oxidation, etc....and should not be a repeat process over the same panels. When the panel is free of scratching(if not too deep), move to finer grit, swirl remover #4, before getting to non-abrasive "show car glaze", and/or wax. Hopefully not letting it get away from you, by washing and waxing often, maintaining the clearcoat...hope this helps.

prompt: is it cardboard? how likely is it to last in rainy weather?
response: There's not going to be a blanket answer to this because so many environments, exposures and paint formulations exist. For me, once a year is all it takes to get the last year's oxidation off. In between I'll do a Show Car Glaze (now called machine glaze) in the spring and fall with the Fine Cut in mid-summer.I use the High-tech yellow wax as a protectant and the car is stored under a car port.

I read that some Honda models have water based paint jobs. It's Hondas attempt at going green. Usually the surfaces(horizontal) are over polished by dealers(or anyone really) because thats the first place we look for a shine and it's the easiest to polish. Just lay the polisher up there and turn it on. Just like a table so, paint is usually thinner there. You can purchase an instument that will measure the thickness of the paint (or ask a reliable shop to do it) check for the differance from roof, hood, trunck then check the side doors and fenders. A polyeurothane clear coat basecoat job can easily cost $3000.00 if done right !

You should check what thread your plugs are.  This kit is for M14 x 1.25 threads.  It comes with three different length inserts to accommodate different reach (thread length) plugs.  M14 x 1.25 means the outside diameter of the threaded surface is 14mm and the distance from one thread to the next (the pitch) is 1.25 mm.  You should be able to Google your plugs and find the thread specs with one of the manufacturers.If you are struggling with this information you are probably out of your depth when it comes to this repair.  If you mess it up, you may need a new cylinder head or at the least you will be taking the head to a machine shop for welding and repair.

prompt: does this come with the wiring harness? as that is what is n/g (burnt) on mine
response:
No. I am speaking specifically for the Acura 3.5 RL.The Tap barely goes beyond the spark plug threads. Remember, at TDC there is still space in the curved part of the head, so don't keep drilling when you think that you've cleared the spark plug hole- measure the length of the spark plug hole and you can figure out how deep you've drilled.  The real issue is making sure that very little metal gets into the cylinder/on the piston; use the Drilling Foam to capture most of the metal pieces and use a vacuum cleaner with a very small rubber hose to vacuum the metal pieces off of the piston. You cannot get out all of the metal, so when you restart the engine it may "miss" a little as the metal burns, BUT the metal will burn inside the cylinder and the engine will quick get back to a normal idle/normal revolution.

prompt: How is this applied?  Do I need adhesive or does the backing peel off?
response:
Yes, the inserts are ferrous.  However, the spark plugs are also ferrous.  Essentially you are screwing a ferrous plug into a ferrous threaded lining which is all threaded into the aluminum block.  The only other real choice is to fully disassemble you head and have the spark plug hole repaired with welding.  Everything will be alloy, but the distortion of the head caused by the welding will require a minimum of the head being planed and possibly camshaft bores being out of alignment, leading  to excess wear of camshaft bearings.PS ... I have used these inserts and they are performing fine in a 2.7 litre turbocharged V6.

prompt: is it the front and back set or just the front want to make sure before i buy
response:
If you are just going to clean-up the spark plug hole threads you can use this tool providing you can get to thew hole.  However, it is less expense to buy a 144mm 1.25 tap for about $6. If you are going to install a Helicoil insert in the hole you first have to enlarge the spark plug hole to 5/8 inch diameter with a 5/8 inch drill which is not included in this kit.  Can you get a drill motor with the 5/8 inch drill aligned with the center line of the hole?  There right angle drill motors which are not as long as a standard. It is very important you drill the hole straight, i.e., on the center line of the spark plug hole and hole must be round and not oval shape to have full hreads for the insert.  You can use a cannister vacuum cleaner with a wand to suck up the drill shavings as you drill.  Some shavings will probably fall into the cylinder.  To get them out I would leave the spark plug out of the hole and turn-over the engine with the starter a few times with ignition coil wire disconnected to blow the shavings out of the cylinder via the open exhaust valve or out the spark plug hole.  The instructions in the kit tell you to use a high temperature thread sealant when installing the Heliciol insert.  This sealant is not included in the kit.  You can order this thread sealant when you order the kit.  I cost $5-$6.

Depends on what "best" means to you.  When you compare the features, accuracy, and price that meets your needs then you have your "best".  I selected the original Fluke 87 over 25 years ago because it offered me everything I needed for a reasonable price and I expected it to last at least 5-10 years.  Selecting the newer Fluke 87-5 when my old one died didn't take much thought.  For my varied uses, electronics, electrician work, automotive, etc. there were many DMMs that would do the job, some cheaper, less accuracy, not as durable construction, or have other features.  I stuck with what I knew worked and kept working.  If you are just checking caps, there's a lot of less expensive choices and ones that will test larger value caps.  If you think you'll be getting more into electronics then a Fluke is a wise long term investment.

That said the feature your most interested in when it comes to DMMs is repeatablity.  Making sure that when you take the measurement with all the same conditions, you get the same result.  That is why I love my 87-V and why its become the first meter I grab when I need a solid base line.

Some of them have much better tack qualities so you can put the cement board in place and it will stay there on its own. JB Weld needs to be clamped in place for 24 hours or so.

response:
Collinite is 100% safe. It is 100% abrasive-free, unlike some other brands that have an ultra-fine grit in addition to carnuba. Collinite carnuba merely adds a layer. It neither removes anything in the process nor does it chemically affect your car's finish. Do one panel at a time and buff as soon as it dries to a haze. Don't let it dry too long before buffing because that makes it very hard to polish to a shine. If you don't like the results it can be removed by washing the car with regular soap (like dish soap). Carnuba wax lasts ONLY IF you wash the car with wax-friendly car wash soap. Good luck!

A: It is recommended that you add the Oil Stabilizer with every oil change (20% Stabilizer, 80% Oil). A; Yes, In addition to being great for your engine, you can also mix it 25% / 75% in the transmission and 50% / 50% in the differential. Lucas Oil Stabilizer blends with any petroleum-based or synthetic oil, and is formulated for gasoline or diesel engines.

response:
NO. It does NOT have any mechanics inside to control such an activity.  This unit is manually applied to tire fill stem and held in place until confirmation of reading beep and then released to view reading.  So, this is all PASSIVE; the button battery power could not have enough energy to be active mechanically.  The battery DOES last a long time - 3 or 4 years, with my use habits which include almost monthly testing.  What it DOES have the capability of is to have memory of what you want your tire settings to be for front and rear tire pairs.  Even this isn't all that helpful.  When using it, it doesn't let you know if it's higher or lower than preset tire pressure goals.  You have to remove it from the stem and check the tested pressure against it's memory of the goal.  Not helpful for me because I have three cars with different tire pressure goals.  I DO like the flashlight and display backlight features because my garage isn't the best lit and these two features help locate stem and apply unit and to see resulting measured pressure.  The 10 seconds display and 10 more seconds until auto shut off settings is sufficient, too.  I recommend this unit.

prompt: Does this wheel bearing fit my honda civic 98 EX?
response:
George, it is exactly 18L x 5H x 5.5W.  With the Siberian express train horns (loudest Wolo makes) it can blast for 18 seconds straight. Want an honest opinion  though? Do not but anything from Wolo. That was my mistake twice. The first thing I got from them was a horn/compressor combo (a small all attached one) I had to send it away to them after 4 months and it took them 6 to finally tell me it couldn't be fixed. I got my money back from the retailer. Then I bought this off of amazon. The first tank I got had a hole in it out of the box! I got a new one a couple weeks later (takes a while to get to Canada) and it was fine. Then after a couple months the compressor went. So I called amazon and they sent me a new set. I now have It mounted in the tool box of my truck and it hasn't faulted so far. However, the rivets Wolo uses on the horns are metal, they rust which I've just found out. It was a stupid design idea to put metal rivets on something that is exposed to the elements and salty roads come winter. Not sure what I'm going to do about that. So my advice is to go with horn blasters. They're better quality and will last a lot longer. I went with this kit because it's cheap but have had nothing but issues. Oh, one more thing. When it hits -20 degrees Celsius the horn solenoid freezes up and you have no train horn.

prompt: Is this fits in my Hyundai Accent 2004?

I'd say that's probably the best way to go.  If the car isn't actually DIRTY, just dusty, you could MAYBE get away with using one of those quick detailer products, then waxing, BUT I'VE NEVER DONE IT THAT WAY.  I'd say give it a try on a SMALL, INCONSPICUOUS area, like maybe a bumper corner...  If it works, GREAT!  If it doesn't work, then at least you haven't wasted the time and effort, and/or ground dirt into your paint.  I always wash the car first - with water and car-wash soap (Nu-Finish Car Wash of course) - rinse it off, probably more than I should, followed by using a super-flexible car care squegee to get most of the water, then towel-drying the rest, followed by waxing.  You don't actually NEED to squeegee the car, but I find it saves towels.  Yes, it takes time, but if you get through first time, following washes/waxes are easier.This may sound a bit off, but if you're pinched for washing, maybe hit one of those touchless car washes, or at least a coin-op place.  Main thing is for the car to be clean, so you're not griding grit into it.  Oh, and just in case you're REALLY new to this, DO NOT - EVER! - JUST DRY-WIPE THE CAR!  That WILL scratch up the paint.  In that case, you'd be better off to just leave the thing dirty.  Your paint will still look bad, but at least it will save you time/effort/money.

prompt: Can I use this oil filter for 2008 BMW 328i
response: Yes and no. It is a protector and polish. My tumbler holds 6 lbs of 50% corn cob / 50% walnut media. I add 3-4 tablespoons of mineral spirits for cleaning and 3-4 tablespoons of NuFinish to each batch of brass I tumble unless I have more than one batch to tumble, then its every 3 batches. You will know when to add more. When you add it let the tumbler run for about 10 minutes before you add the brass. You need to have no clumps in it or it will get inside the brass and dry up. I also toss in a few cut up used dryer sheets to control dust.

response:
Ok, here's the ONLY correct answer: 1st of all, Nu-Finish is a WAX-FREE POLISH. Polishing a car for example, especially dark/Black cars that have some light swirling (Spider webs) & light scratches NEED MUCH MORE THAN NU-FINISH. Now, there are 4 steps to properly "detail"(Polish/Wax/Simonizing) any paint-maintained vehicle. They are Washing/drying, pre-cleaning, POLISHING FOR SHINE, & finally WAXING FOR PROTECTION/SEALING.Using just 1 product of ANY BRAND will not accomplish much EXCEPT TO THOSE WHO DON'T KNOW BETTER. Nu-Finish is the only Car Polish that for years had tremendous Marketing benefits, mainly their junkyard before & after commercials. So, people believed what they saw, purchased this product & GOT THE RESULTS THEY WERE HOPING FOR, just like in the commercial. However, the commercial never would dare put an infrared light & closeup shot of the REAL RESULTS. What we would have seen was a dull, swirl-marked "Dead" finish. Clever, yes indeed-comparing 1 totally oxidized/weathered & ruined side next to a freshly polished side. Had they shown a new car hood next to the "Nu-Finished" side, then your eyes would tell your brain that it was all just an illusion.So, let's start with say, a 2 year old car that was only washed thru automatic car-wash places. Black finish. What you have is a car with fine "Swirls/scratches/spider webs" & some noticeable scratches. Use only Nu Finish & you'll get a great shine, but nothing more. All of the damage I mentioned will still remain. Use Nu-Finish right out of the showroom on a brand new car & micro-fiber CLEAN cloths to wipe it off (And ONLY HAND WASH!), & you'll always have a "Like new" paint job. ANYTHING OTHER THAN THAT, NU-FINISH IS SIMPLY A SEMI-ABRASIVE POLISH & SYNTHETIC "PROTECTOR", and there are dozens of 2 to 4 step products that if used on 2 exactly the same condition vehicles like the one I created here, & Nu-Finish will not even come close to the other vehicle's results IN ANY WAY.And to answer your question which you can do a search on, asking "The difference between Polishing & Waxing", you will learn that POLISHING IS FOR SHINE/fine scratches ETC.& WAXING IS FOR SEALING IN THAT SHINE-BUT DOES NOT ADD SHINE. WHEN USING THE CORRECT 4 STEP PROCEDURE & TOP-RATED PRODUCTS which are inexpensive & much better quality products like Meguiars, Griots, Pinnacle, and yes, TURTLE WAX PRODUCTS STILL AMONG THE BEST (SEARCH FOR THEM AS WELL. NU-FINISH IS NOT ON EVEN 1 PROFESSIONAL "TOP 10 CAR POLISHES" LIST!), you will not believe the difference. Whoever uses this product & is happy with the results is either brainwashed by the commercial, used it from the beginning & tried nothing else ("Professional" or high-end), or THINKS they cannot get better results from anything else. Spend a TOTAL of say 30.00 on a well-known Pre-wax cleaner/Polish/Swirl mark remover & Wax and do 1/2 your hood with those, 1/2 with Nu-Finish. Only then will you see what you're missing, & IT'LL BE LIKE NIGHT & DAY!  You have nothing at all to lose as you will return the Nu-Finish & be WELL EDUCATED on how to CORRECTLY MAINTAIN YOUR SHINY & PROTECTED, MUCH "NEWER" FINISH!

How to Remove the NU Finish From Plastic (thumbnail)   By Anne Lee, eHow ContributorKeep the shine on the paint, not on the trim. Nu Finish is a car polish introduced on the market in 1976. Nu Finish is famous for its ability to make an older car shine like new with one yearly application. It is used primarily on the painted surface of a car. Nu Finish is available in a liquid base polish or paste and is applied with a damp cloth; after drying it will protect your car's finish. If you use Nu Finish on a surface such as plastic trim, vinyl or rubber you will notice a white residue that you may want to remove. prompt: Is drilling the bed required?
response:
It depends on how dull the paint is.  Rubbing compound takes off the dull (oxidized) paint in addition to some of the good paint under it.  Polishing compound is like rubbing compound except it's less aggressive (less abrasive) then rubbing compound.  A pure wax (like Collinite) has no polish in it.  Most "waxes" like Nu Finish have some polishing compound in them but it is usually not very aggressive and won't help an extremely dull paint. Some people think "wax" and "polish" are the same.  I would try the following: First try Nu Finish alone on a small area. If that does not work try a hand polishing compound followed by Nu Finish. If that doesn't work try hand rubbing compound then Nu Finish. You will see the color of paint on the rag you are using to polish, rub or wax. That is what is supposed to happen.  Hand rubbing a finish is a lot of work.  If that doesn't work, or is just too much work, you should machine buff the car. If there is any good paint below the oxidized layer that should do the job. For any of the products mentioned apply as per the instructions on the can.  DO NOT apply a polishing compound after waxing.  That will just take the protective wax off.  I have used Nu Finish a number of times and it is a good product.  Don't expect it to last anywhere near a full year.

response:
This is the instructions I found on dicor's website hope it helps.BRITE-PLY ROOFING SYSTEM RETRO-FIT INSTALLATION GUIDE The instructions contained herein are guidelines for installing BRITE-PLY EPDM rubber roofing on older RV's. When applied using the proper techniques, materials, and tools, the BRITE-PLY roof should provide years of dependable, trouble free performance. To ensure proper warranty coverage, you should adhere to the installation techniques and materials described in this installation guide. Use of other procedures and products may jeopardize your warranty coverage.Note: Read fully and understand the procedures before beginning installation.1. Tools and Materials: A. Waterbased adhesive (901-BA) is applied to a wood substrate with a roller. The BRITE-PLY roofing is applied while the adhesive is still wet. B. Butyl tape (BT-1834) must be under all vents and accessories on the roof and termination moldings that contact the EPDM roofing. Butyl tape should also be used under the EPDM membrane where it comes in contact with the unit body at the front, rear, and side terminations. C. Lap sealant (501-LS) is a self-leveling caulk used to seal screw-type fasteners and termination moldings, formulated especially for BRITE-PLY EPDM roofing. D. Paint roller (not supplied) should be 9" wide short nap type. Used to apply waterbased adhesive (901-BA). E. Push broom or squeegee (not supplied) used to remove air pockets and ensure that the EPDM membrane is completely in contact with the adhesive. F. Caulking gun (not supplied) used to apply lap sealant (501-LS). G. Roof decking (substrate, not supplied), depending on the roof load requirements, should be at least 1/8" luan plywood. If the load requirements are heavy (storage pods or consistent traffic) a minimum of 1/2" plywood is recommended. In most new unit applications, 1/4" luan or plywood is the minimum material used, while 3/8" material is more prevalent.NOTE: Dicor does not warrant selection of substrate material. Feel free to contact Dicor with any questions.2. Cleaning Information: You will notice a powdery, white talc on the surface of your BRITE-PLY EPDM roof membrane. This talc is used in the manufacturing process of the membrane. While this talc will not interfere with the performance of your BRITE-PLY roof, and it will eventually be removed by the natural elements, it is recommended that you clean the membrane within a week after installation.BRITE-PLY EPDM roofing can be cleaned with Dicor Rubber Roof Cleaner. For stubborn stains, products containing mineral spirits are recommended. Do not use Acetone or Citrus Cleaners. Do not let any cleaning solvent come in contact with the membrane for extended periods of time. Because dust and dirt may collect on the roof, regular cleaning with Dicor's RP-RC160C or RP-RC320S Rubber Roof Cleaner is recommended. Do not park vehicle for extended periods where roof will be exposed to tree sap or fruit as staining may result. A soft bristle brush may be used during cleaning.Preparation 1. Remove all appliances, vents, moldings, etc. that may inhibit the current roofing material from being removed. 2. Evaluate the old roof. BRITE-PLY roofing must have a sturdy foundation. Determine if the entire roof should be removed, or if the addition of decking (substrate) will be sufficient. Remember that the substrate must be securely fastened on all edges and seams. 3. Either remove the old roof or apply the substrate over the old roof, if removal will create structural damage. 4. When applying the substrate, make sure it extends to the edges of the roof. Also, make sure all seams are tight and as level as possible. The substrate should be applied using screw-type fasteners with screw heads level or slightly below the surface of the substrate. All substrate seams should be on a rafter for necessary support and to reduce the possibility of "seam separation". If seams are wider than 1/16" you may want to bridge seams with Dicor Fleece Tape 511FT. Additionally, if on the roof edge, the membrane will be going over a sharp edge, you should either bevel the edge of the substrate with a sander or place the Dicor Fleece Tape 511FT over the edge to protect the membrane from the edge. 5. Route-out or cut all vent and appliance openings. 6. Broom or blow-off of substrate all foreign materials and check entire roof for exposed screw heads or sharp objects that may prematurely wear the BRITEPLY roof.Installation 1. Locate the ends (front and rear) where the BRITE-PLY roof will be terminated. Use a chalk-line to mark these areas. Make sure there is sufficient roof structure to fasten to. 2. Cover the roof with the BRITE-PLY membrane making sure there is sufficient length at both the front and rear termination points. Fold membrane in-half, exposing the roof areas. 3. Open the waterbased adhesive (901-BA) and stir thoroughly. Using a 9" wide short nap paint roller, apply adhesive to the substrate at a rate of 160 sq. ft. per gallon. The membrane is to be mated with the adhesive as quickly as possible.4. Fold the membrane the opposite direction and repeat step #3. 5. With the membrane in place, adjust to make sure there is sufficient length at both termination points and on both sides of the vehicle. Remove wrinkles by lifting and pulling the membrane. Do not stretch the rubber membrane. 6. Lightly squeegee or broom to eliminate air pockets, making sure the membrane is completely in contact with the adhesive. 7. Apply butyl tape (BT-1834) to the side of the roof edge molding. While holding the molding, draw surplus material tight with a downward pull. (You may staple the membrane in-place spacing 1/2" staples 3-5" apart to keep proper tension.) For best results, install this molding from the center of the vehicle toward the ends. When complete, use a utility knife to cut surplus material from below the molding. Repeat on opposite side.NOTE: It may helpful to strike a chalk line to assist in keeping the side-body molding straight and in proper position.8. Apply butyl tape (BT-1834) to the termination molding. On the front, the front cap should lay on top of the membrane. Using a screw-type fastener, install the termination moldings - making sure there is sufficient roof structure. On the rear of the vehicle, the membrane should lay on top of the rear cap.NOTE: Butyl tape should also be used under the EPDM membrane where it comes in contact with the unit body at the front, rear, and side terminations. See all termination drawings for correct butyl placement. 9. Using a utility knife "X" cut all roof openings. Make sure all openings are cut the same size as previous openings. Round all 90 degree cuts to eliminate "running cuts". Surplus material should be stapled inside vent openings. Do not stretch the rubber membrane. Trim all excess material. 10. Apply butyl tape (BT-1834) to all appliances, vents, etc. Re-install using screw-type fasteners. When installing the vents, appliances, etc. you may notice that the BRITE-PLY membrane near the screws begins to "creep" and small air pockets form. Simply "walk" the bubble toward the opening and hold-in-place while installing screw-type fasteners.Caulk all screw heads, front and rear termination bar and all accessories.Note: Only Butyl Tape can be used with Brite-Ply membrane to assure proper seal. 11. Install lap sealant (501-LS) using a 1/4" to 3/8" bead, as follows: A. Bridging the membrane on all appliances. B. Both ends of the front and rear termination molding. C. Top edge of side roof edge molding. D. All screw heads located on the roof.NOTE: Do not use silicone - it will not adhere to the EPDM rubber. 12. Clean all surplus caulk and debris from the roof.NOTE: If the unit has a fiberglass or metal side radius cap, a bonding adhesive may be used in these areas. Normally, pulling the membrane tight under the side edge roof molding will be sufficient. If you determine a bonding adhesive is necessary, please call Dicor for additional information.

prompt: where is this made?
response:
Go to centricparts.com to confirm but according to them, all LX/LX-P use this rotor.  This was a superior rotor to original Honda rotors.  Since you have a 2010, the two screws holding the rotor on may not be heat welded to the rotor but I STRONGLY, STRONGLY recommend two things to make your life MUCH better: A) order an impact driver Powerbuilt 648002 1/2-Inch Drive Impact Driver Kit for about $12 from Amazon when you buy the rotors.  If you strip the Phillips screws (as VERY often happens with a regular screwdriver), you will have a TON of frustration trying to change the rotors. 2) take the screws to a GOOD hardware store (Ace, True Value, etc.) that has a huge assortment of screws.  Get a HEX DRIVE metric screw to put in the place of the STUPID Phillips screws - they can be a longer length than the factory screws - no problem.  USE ANTI SEIZE LUBE sparingly on the new screws.  Talk to anyone who replaces Honda brakes and they will each have at least 1 horror story about the rotor screws.  Honda engineers need to have their n**ts squeezed for this simple goof that has tortured a generation of mechanics.

prompt: Can it be used on all types of vehicles. I have a Lexus CT.
response:
In my opinion K&N; makes the best filter out there. Your car's owner's manual will give you an unbelievably high interval but I'm not comfortable with this. Synthetic oil holds up better than dino (petroleum) oil and can go longer before breaking down. Some people will go up 12K miles between oil changes and then change the filter every other time, but I'm just not comfortable with this because oil is also a cleaner as well as a lube. The filter merely keeps the micro-grit out of it. I change my synthetic oil and filter together at 5K mile intervals on all of my cars, which is probably too often. But I figure this is cheap insurance. I buy my cars to keep as long as possible, so I take extra care of them. I hope this answers your question.

prompt: what does "class 2.5" mean
response:
Not sure what your specific query is. Spark plu gap specification partly determined by the engine designer. A larger gap can produce a bigger spark however requires more energy and is subjected to further quenching effect with higher compression engines. Correct Gap is important for efficient operation of the spark plug and engine. The gap can be checked prior installation with a spark plug gap gage or otherwise feeler gages. This plug is metric, so is typically gapped to specification at 0.8mm from the factory or approximately 0.03". Most of the time it can be installed straight out of the box without further adjustment of gap.

response: My 2001 Camry takes the Calif. version though it's from Georgia so check the emissions tag on the underside of the hood for whether it says it meets "US"or "US AND Calif." emissions.  In 2001 the US standards just required an oxygen sensor, the Calif. one requires the air/fuel ratio sensor.  Mine says US and Calif.  Luckily the connectors are different so I couldn't plug this model sensor in.  You'll make a really big mistake if you get the Universal fit version of this sensor and unwittingly splice it into a "Calif." car.

I think it would help with making the engine run better if the problem is due to old gasoline deposits gumming up the carburetor.  The Berryman cleaner is mixed with the gas in the tank - about 1 oz. per tankful of gas.  But if the engine isn't firing at all then I'm not sure this additive will get it working again.  It will work best if the engine is running (even roughly) so that the cleaner can be drawn through the carburetor in order to clean the parts.  If the engine isn't running you might put the cleaner in the gas and try to get it into the carb by attempting to start the engine.  I would just let it sit for a few hours and then try starting again.  If that doesn't work then you may need to disassemble the carb and clean it or rebuild it.

Did you replace these because you had codes saying these were bad? If you had codes saying that all 3 oxygen sensors were bad then you probably replaced good sensors. Or did you replace them thinking they might fix your problem? If the later is the situation, then you need to get the trouble codes to see what's going on. If you have access to live data on your scan tool, all 3 oxygen sensors should have a voltage fluctuating up and down around 0.5 volts, meaning one moment you will see something like 0.8 volts and the next 0.3 volts and constantly fluctuating when the vehicle is at operating temperature. If they are fluctuating like i explained previously then they are doing what they are supposed to do. If you put in new sensors and they stay fixed like 0.8 (rich) or 0.2 volts (lean), then you have problems with fuel metering (injectors, fuel pressure regulator, temp sensor, misfire (bad coils),etc). Good luck!

It's recommended you change both dep. on mileage tho - which means "yes" if you're clutch lasted more than 70K~100K miles.(a harsh or rattling idle can indicate a worn DMF as well as "clunks" while tipping into/out-of throttle aggressively)

prompt: Will these fit on an 04 FXST softail standard?
response:
The 5-speed/6-speed difference may apply to VW, but I learned the hard way today that at least for the Mk1 Audi TT Quattro (1999-2006) the 5 and 6-speed transmission use the same clutch, the Luk 02040. The service manual even states, in place of 6th gear, the 5-speed transmission has a spacer. I can find no differences in the service manual between the 5 and 6-speed manual transmissions, just different gear ratios and the spacer.The other key difference, the Luk 17050, which Luk's site lists as the clutch for the TT Quattro 5-speed, has the wrong throw-out bearing. The 5-speed uses the same throw-out bearing with an integrated slave cylinder, just like the 6-speed. Yes, I am saying the Luk web site is wrong, I called them today and went through a long discussion with a tech rep (not customer service), he was surprised to learn the 5-speed uses the integrated throw-out bearing/slave cylinder. Luk in the US is actually just a distributor, they are NOT part of the Luk company according to this tech rep, so they do not get "inside" info that Luk may have on special situations, which appears to apply to the Mk1 Audi TT Quattro 5-speeds.

It means that this filter has a large enough capacity to filter your oil effectively for 15,000 miles.  It also means that the filter element is constructed of synthetic fiber that will not break down for that long. Theoretically if you use a high quality oil like Mobil 1 Extended Performance, in which the additives will not break down for 15,000 miles, you do not need to change it until that mileage or 1 year has been reached.  That being said, as an auto tech I personally would not go any longer than 6 months or 10k.  Any manufacturer will suggest following their recomendations regardless of oil and oil filter type.  This is an especially good idea if your car is still under waranty, as deviation from manfacturer-scheduled service will likely void your waranty.

I am sure it would fit fine.  They are certainly strong enough to hold any normal sized car.  I used them on a 2007 ford fusion and they worked well.  You can rent them from auto stores but honestly I liked these better because of the retainer pins.  They will save you a ton of money in the end.  Since you are getting this I would also recommend replacing the bump stops and the bearings.  Yes struts have bearings in them.  The need to be able to rotate a little.  One side of mine was seized up.  Just remember you should replace things in pairs.  You should probably get an alignment once done.  Because of this and the price of the parts you might as well do all four wheels.For safety I highly recommend having someone else around to keep an eye on you from a distance.  This is the most dangerous repair you can do on a car.  It is not bad if you use common sense, but the results of failure can be, well....deadly.  Take your time and do it right.

I put a set on a 1996 F150. Worked nicely. Caution: If you have dual gas tanks look on the inside of the frame BEFORE drilling! There can be gas lines, brake lines, etc., hiding back there. The Ford frames haven't changed a lot in 20+ years so I would imagine these would fit. Again...Look before you drill. Also, DO NOT run these bags without some air in them! Five to ten PSI is good. And, secure the air line twice as much as you think it needs. The tail pipe gets hot enough to melt the plastic lines. And you're going to hate drilling a couple of the holes, unless you're ambidextrous. Assemble everything, SNUG the hardware down.....DO NOT tighten all the way first time around. Make sure it all fits and clears. Put wheels back on.....yes, they need to come off. Look very closely, make sure everything clears everything else under there. Then crank the hardware down. And torque it all good. These bags are great.....but not "plug-n-play"!

response:
My Silverado has a spray-on Rhinoliner, and the seal works fine. Unlike my Chevy, which has a very irregular surface where you need to attach the seal - the Dodge trucks that I've seen have a nice, flat surface perpendicular to the bed floor where the bottom of the tailgate "meets" the bed. Your spray-on liner is probably not applied there, you should have an ideal clean, flat surface for the seal's adhesive tape to adhere. The lower portion of the tailgate that meets the seal can have the spray-on liner - the seal will crush against it, and there shouldn't be any significant infiltration along that surface. You WILL have some infiltration at the corners - spray-on liner or not. I get a slight amount of dust, but no water. I do not drive dirt or gravel roads.

response:
Well Travel Trailer scissor jacks and not meant to "Lift" the RV.  They are just to stabilize it.  This is a basic bottle jack with 6 ton capacity.  Technically it can lift 12,000 pounds.  If you want to lift corners of your TT for leveling you would need to use some kind of block from your frame to your jack.  You do NOT put a jack like this under your scissor jacks.  On a TT side to side leveling is done by using some form of blocking under the tire (I keep some short 1x6 boards on hand for this).  Front to back leveling is done with the front tongue jack.  Once you RV is level you then lower your scissor jack to stabilize it.

prompt: Will an SZ343 work on a 2013 or 14 Jeep Compass?
response:
The boot is sized to the specific KYB strut/shock for the application. Many (most?) times there is a different strut for all four corners of your vehicle, and two corresponding boots that are different for the front and rear of the car. The factory application is likely to use a similar boot. If I were to replace my struts again, I might use an aftermarket, universal fit boot rather than the KYB part. Check the KYB website for your specific application and also for rebates. I found an unexpected $40 rebate after the fact.  Also, be careful when you search for deals using the KYB part numbers as many unscrupulous manufacturers or dealers use the KYB part numbers as to confuse you into buying their parts.  No biggy for boots, but a BIG deal for shocks/struts. Good luck!

The wiring instructions that came with my Reese Towpower 74377 POD brake controller, although helpful, were pretty basic and specific to my Ford F-150. Obviously, electrical systems vary, sometimes dramatically, from one vehicle to another, so I'm assuming that the instructions that came with my POD would be different from, say, your Tundra. You might be able to get wiring info from the vehicle manufacturer or from Reese (They are a product of Cequent Performance Products - http://www.reeseprod.com/content/contactus.aspx). They were very helpful when I contacted them with a question. Once you obtain the wire coloring schematic, installation should be fairly easy. Also, the wiring harness that I ordered had good wiring instructions, but, again were specific to my Ford. Hope this is helpful info.

prompt: would this rims fit a 2006 f 150
response:
Stan,Yes they give you instructions. The controler comes with a wire harness, a connector is on the end of it that you might want to remove and use the wire ends. You probably could order and adapter plug for the Tundra but running the wires yourself will save money. The  Hopkins 47185 Multi-Tow Adapter $20.27 has all the wire connections for the rear already prewired. You will need to run 2 12 guage wires from the connector in the rear, one to the controler (Blue) for the Brakes and one to the battery for 12 Volt power to connector if you think you need it back there (RED). Also a 12 guage wire from the battery to the controler (RED). The controler has 4 wires coming from it. 12V Power (RED), Ground (WHITE), Brake wire (BLUE) and a wire (BLACK) that connects under the dash to the stoplite switch at the brake pedal. The ground wire may be long enough, but the rest need to be extended. Use the proper guage wires. The multi tow adapter has all the wires you need to hook up the Tail and Right and Left turn signals, but they to are in a 4 pin plug that is of no use. Cut it off and extend the wires you need to the tail lights. You will need Hopkins 48615 Mounting Bracket $4.98 also. You might need to get a repair manual from Auto Zone to find the correct wires under the dash by the brake and for the Tail and Turn Signals. Hope this helps.Mike

What they likely mean is that it isn't "plug & play", it would likely mean you have to run your own wiring for 12 volts, ground, and also tap into the brake light circuitry (which the harness from Toyota may furnish for you).  You may want to check with a electrical technician at a local Toyota dealership. They likely have one or two techs that specialize in troubleshooting electrical problems, who can help you without even looking it up.  Generally if you just stop into the service shot and ask the supervisor or service writer if you can ask them a quick question, they point you in the right direction.  In Summary, I can't see why it wouldn't function properly, it just might take the running of a couple of extra wires.  By the way, I have this unit on my ol' 1996 Chev pickup and it works great.  Good luck!

When wiring the +12 (black wire) and ground (white wire) to the brake controller be sure to use at least #14 guage for 1-2 axle applications, and #12 for 3-4 axles at a minimum.  This includes both to the controller and from the controller to the trailer connection (blue wire). Make sure trailer connection also has a good ground (white) of at least #14 or #12 guage wire.  One or two axle trailers generally require a 20 amp auto reset circuit breaker.  Three or four axle trailers require a 30 amp auto reset circuit breaker.  These are available for less than $10 at most any auto store.  They come with slide on or bolt type connections, either one is fine.  Do not use a fuse, it can lead to problems.  Use good solder or crimp connectors only. Good luck.  I installed this on my older '96 Chevy diesel pickup, which was not prewired except for two unused lines running from the driver's firewall to the rear bumper area.  It was an easy hookup.  It's an easy to use controller that works great on my large two axle travel trailer.  You should be pleased with it.

Radio Shack or most other stores/websites that have a good electronics section. The AC adapter that came with mine doesn't even say Black and Decker on it. I used a label-maker to label it "booster". The input is 120 volt, 60Hz AC of course, the output is 12 volts, 500mA, center pin positive. It's vital that you the polarity (center pin positive) and amperage (500 mA or more) is correct on the power adapter, or damage could occur! I measured it with a micrometer, the outer diameter of the plug is 5.5mm, the inner diameter is 2.5mm. So, the Radioshack catalog #273-357 paired with the Adaptaplug N (catalog #273-345) should work. With the adaptaplug, you flip the tip around to change polarity.

prompt: Are mounting bracketts included?
response:
The reason manufacturers say not to connect the negative clamp to the battery is to minimize sparking. When batteries are charging, they produce a tiny amount of hydrogen gas, which is explosive. Modern batteries are low/no maintenance however, and vent very little hydrogen, so there isn't much risk, unless you are charging for hours. If you use a charger, leave the hood fully open to vent gas, and choose the slowest charging speed that works for the situation. Engines generally have lifting hooks attached to them. If this hook is not painted, and the battery terminals are clean this is usually a good place to attach to. Otherwise, look for a cable going from the negative battery post to the frame/engine. There will be a bolt there. This is electrically the best place to connect, other than the battery itself. If the battery terminals are corroded, the best thing to do is to clean them before jump starting.

prompt: what color is this tray?
response:
Milton, The thread to thread measurement is really not important to know. If you must though, the Stant #10413 Fuel Cap is intended for use on male pipe thread 2" nominal inside diameter. According to the National Pipe Thread Taper (NPT) Charts, a 2" nominal pipe thread has 11-1/2 threads per inch. The best way to determine if this fuel cap will fit your tank is to go to Home Depot or Lowes or Plumbing Supply house and buy a white plastic or steel (black iron or galvanized) 2" diameter cap or coupling. If the cap or coupling fits the male nipple inlet on your fuel tank to your satisfaction, then buy the 10413 Fuel cap. I have bought 2 of these caps for our Bobtail trucks (40-50 gal tanks) and they work perfectly. Tom

prompt: Is this a set?
response: I have no way to know if the Stant 10413 cap fits the diesel tank on your truck. What I know for sure is this cap fits on 2" diameter NPT (Nat'l Pipe Thread) male nipple typically welded to diesel tank for filling purposes. What I did to confirm the 2" size on our truck tank was go to Home Depot (or Lowes or Orchard) and buy a 2" white plastic cap (or coupling) with the NPT threads. Less than a dollar. If the 2" NPT cap easily threads on your tank fill nipple, then order the Stant cap. It works well for us, has a key lock tab that presses against the inside of nipple wall.

prompt: Will this work for a 2015 pilot?
response:
Barak, I don't know if the Stant 10413 cap fits the diesel tank on your International truck line. What I know for sure is this cap fits on 2" diameter NPT (Nat'l Pipe Thread) male nipple that is typically welded to diesel tank for filling purposes. What I did to confirm the 2" size on our truck tank was go to Home Depot (or Lowes or Orchard) and buy a 2" white plastic cap (or coupling) specified with the 2" NPT threads. Less than a dollar. If the 2" NPT cap easily threads on your tank fill nipple, then order the Stant cap. It works well for us, has a key lock tab that presses against the inside of wall of pipe. I did have to sand the lock tab down a bit to allow the key to turn all the way for tight fit. Depends on thickness of your pipe wall. Hope this helps.

response:
The female port is called the common port and is labelled with a "C".  If your intended use is to divert from one port to either of the other two, the intended application, then you must use the female as the inlet.  However, the valve could be used in a reverse application where both male ports are used as inlets, and the female becomes the outlet. For example one male could be connected to a cold water supply, and the other male could be connected to a hot water supply.  Handle in one position sends cold to the female port, while in the other position it sends hot.  It would not be a good mixer valve since one male is nearly closed before the other starts to open.  The common port is never closed.  Each of the male ports are alternately closed depending on handle position.

prompt: Will this fit on a 2014 Civic Si Coupe?
response:
Hi Deborah,  The rest of the RV plumbing will work just as before switching to bypass.  You will need to drain the water tank after making sure that you have turned off your electrical element by turning off the switch or tripping the Water Heater circuit breaker. The low point drains should work just as before and you need to open your hot and cold valves on all of your faucets until all the water has drained out of the low point drains.  Once the water is all out of the low point drains and your water heater. close the low point drains, close all the faucets, and charge the system with RV antifreeze opening one faucet (including the commode) at a time until you see the pink  liquid then close the valve.  Dump the excess antifreeze into each sink and the toilet after all the outlets of the sinks, outside shower, inside shower have been charged with antifreeze.  Use the RV's water pump inlet to suck the antifreeze from the container to charge the lines.  Most RV's will need three gallons or less.
